content:
Reference: Plantain Cake Making
Ingredients For serving size of 1 cake in 9x9 diameter cake
2 ripe plantains 2 cups flour 1 tsp Salt 1 Tsp baking powder 1/4 Tsp baking soda 3/4 cup sugar 8 tbsp butter or 1 stick butter 1/4 cup Yogurt 2 eggs 3 tbsp milk 1 tsp vanilla extract Recipe Preheat the oven to 350°F, then grease and flour the baking pan and set aside. Combine the flour, salt, and baking powder and baking soda. Whisk, mash or blend the plantains till fairly smooth. Use a hand whisk to cream the butter and sugar for 2 to 3 minutes. Add the eggs one at a time and cream together until just combined. Add the Yogurt and vanilla and whisk together. Mix the mashed plantains with the creamed butter and add the mixture to the dry ingredients (flour, salt, and baking powder). Fold a couple of times until well mixed. (don’t over mix). Stir in the milk and mix till combined. Mix chocolate chips, some nuts such as almonds, cashews, walnuts for crunchy texture (optional) Pour the batter into the prepared baking pan. Smooth out the surface of the batter and bake for 50 minutes to 1 hr or till a tester or toothpick inserted into the middle of the cake comes out clean. Let the cake cool down and then cut it and serve!
summary:
Reference:

Plantain Cake Making

Ingredients

For serving size of 1 cake in 9x9 diameter cake

  1. 2 ripe plantains
  2. 2 cups flour
  3. 1 tsp Salt
  4. 1 Tsp baking powder
  5. 1/4 Tsp baking soda
  6. 3/4 cup sugar
  7. 8 tbsp butter or 1 stick butter
  8. 1/4 cup Yogurt
  9. 2 eggs
  10. 3 tbsp milk
  11. 1 tsp vanilla extract

Recipe

  1. Preheat the oven to 350°F, then grease and flour the baking pan and set aside.
  2. Combine the flour, salt, and baking powder and baking soda.
  3. Whisk, mash or blend the plantains till fairly smooth.
  4. Use a hand whisk to cream the butter and sugar for 2 to 3 minutes. Add the eggs one at a time and cream together until just combined. Add the Yogurt and vanilla and whisk together.
  5. Mix the mashed plantains with the creamed butter and add the mixture to the dry ingredients (flour, salt, and baking powder). Fold a couple of times until well mixed. (don’t over mix).
  6. Stir in the milk and mix till combined.
  7. Mix chocolate chips, some nuts such as almonds, cashews, walnuts for crunchy texture (optional)
  8. Pour the batter into the prepared baking pan. Smooth out the surface of the batter and bake for 50 minutes to 1 hr or till a tester or toothpick inserted into the middle of the cake comes out clean.
  9. Let the cake cool down and then cut it and serve!
title: Plantaincake

content:
My investment research for USA:
Only invest if: You have no debts You have a 6-month emergency fund You’ve maxed out your 401k You’ve maxed out your IRA Brokerage accounts Fidelity Charles Schwab Vanguard Types of funds: Retirement: Can be taken out past 59.5 years 10% penalty for early withdrawal
401k (pre-tax, saves on taxable income) upto 23,000$ per year upto a percentage of the base will be contributed by the companies will not be considered as taxable income Roth IRA (post-tax, saves on being taxed during withdrawal) upto 6500$ per year can be made only from income that is taxed (i.e no other source) has to be within income i.e if income is < 2k, cant deposit more than 2k into roth Key Note: Both can be further invested into index funds
Investment: Index Funds vs ETF’s:
Index mutual funds can only be bought and sold at the end of the trading day, based on the fund’s net asset value (NAV). ETFs trade throughout the day on a stock exchange, just like stocks, and their price fluctuates based on supply and demand. ETF’s are more tax efficient because they minimize capital gain whereas index funds are more prone to this tax (hasn’t happened in past few years tho) Types of Index funds: Comparison Tool a. Track Market Trends:
Fidelity FXAIX = S&P500 FSKAX = Total US Market Capture (~3800 companies) FTIHX = International (outside US) FZROX = (recommended for Roth) FXNAX = Diversified between US Gov’t and Corporate Bonds Vanguard VOO = S&P 500 (ETF) VFIAX = S&P 500 (Fund) VTI = Total US Market Capture (ETF) VTSAX = Total US Market Capture (Fund) VYM = Vanguard High Yield Dividend ETF Detailed Differences Comparison Fidelity Vanguard Charles Schwab Expense Ratio (S&P 500) 0.015% (FXAIX) 0.04% (VFIAX), 0.03% (VOO) 0.02% (SWPPX) Things to Consider before selecting the fund Who runs the fund and how long have they been at the helm. What other funds do they run? What is the fund’s investment strategy? What are the specific risks of this strategy besides the general risks of investing. How has the fund been performing compared to some industry benchmark and other funds with a similar investing strategy. Percentage of diversification (recommended is 70% us market, 20% international, 10% bonds) Terms to Know: Margin Interest Rates:
we can borrow money against the principle being the stock that we own in the brokerage. this is how the brokerages make money. Expense Ratio:
percentage of the investment in the fund that is paid for owning the fund. References: Fidelity vs Vanguard vs Charles Schwab
Index Mutual Funds vs ETFs
Portfolio Management
Average Annual Returns Comparison
summary:
My investment research for USA:

Only invest if:

  • You have no debts
  • You have a 6-month emergency fund
  • You’ve maxed out your 401k
  • You’ve maxed out your IRA

Brokerage accounts

  1. Fidelity
  2. Charles Schwab
  3. Vanguard

Types of funds:

Retirement:

Can be taken out past 59.5 years
10% penalty for early withdrawal

  1. 401k (pre-tax, saves on taxable income)
    • upto 23,000$ per year
    • upto a percentage of the base will be contributed by the companies
    • will not be considered as taxable income
  2. Roth IRA (post-tax, saves on being taxed during withdrawal)
    • upto 6500$ per year
    • can be made only from income that is taxed (i.e no other source)
    • has to be within income i.e if income is < 2k, cant deposit more than 2k into roth

Key Note: Both can be further invested into index funds
title: IntroToInvesting

content:
Step 1: hugo new –kind page posts/Post_Name.md Step 2: update the content Step 2.5: update base url with hugo -b url Step 3: hugo server Step 4: hugo –minify (prod build)
Step 4: navigate to public/ folder and git push
Video Tutorial https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LIFvgrRxdt4&t=1s
summary:
Step 1: hugo new –kind page posts/Post_Name.md
Step 2: update the content
Step 2.5: update base url with hugo -b url
Step 3: hugo server
Step 4: hugo –minify (prod build)
Step 4: navigate to public/ folder and git push

Video Tutorial

https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=LIFvgrRxdt4&t=1s
title: CreatingHugoPost

content:
Sonarcloud: Useful to get static code analysis.
Configuration with Azure Pipelines:
# Prepare SonarQube analysis configuration. - task: SonarQubePrepare@3 inputs: SonarQube: # string. scannerMode: 'MSBuild' cliProjectKey: # string. Required when scannerMode = CLI && configMode = manual. Project Key. projectKey: # string. Guidelines:
Ensure to use version 3 and above. Previous ones are deprecated and will not be able to find the generated test analysis files. If the code and tests are under the same src folder, then write the files that need to be excluded in the .xml file: <ItemGroup> <TestProjects Include="src/Tests/**/*.csproj" /> </ItemGroup>
summary:
Sonarcloud: Useful to get static code analysis.

Configuration with Azure Pipelines:

# Prepare SonarQube analysis configuration.
- task: SonarQubePrepare@3
  inputs:
    SonarQube: # string. 
    scannerMode: 'MSBuild'
    cliProjectKey: # string. Required when scannerMode = CLI && configMode = manual. Project Key. 
    projectKey: # string.

Guidelines:

  1. Ensure to use version 3 and above. Previous ones are deprecated and will not be able to find the generated test analysis files.
  2. If the code and tests are under the same src folder, then write the files that need to be excluded in the .xml file:
<ItemGroup>
    <TestProjects Include="src/Tests/**/*.csproj" />
</ItemGroup>
title: Sonarcloudlearning
